key_points: Gabby Petito and Brian Laundrie were involved in a domestic dispute in Moab, Utah, before her demise.
BODY CAMERA footage released by Moab City Police Department reveals officers identified Petito as the aggressor.
Incident raises questions about police handling of domestic violence and biases in determining aggressors.
Utah's mandatory arrest law for domestic violence incidents aimed to ensure serious enforcement by police.
Rita Smith, an advocate, expresses concern over the rise in arrests of domestic violence survivors due to these laws.
Experts criticize the binary approach to intimate partner violence that only recognizes a victim or an aggressor.
Police ultimately did not charge Petito, but the incident shows the flawed systems domestic violence victims face.
Calls for alternative methods of handling domestic violence that include de-escalation and support instead of criminalization.
Domestic violence survivors often face alienation from the legal system, which discourages future reporting.
Petito's case exemplifies broader issues of systemic failure to support domestic violence victims adequately.
spokespersons: Rita Smith (Former Head, National Coalition Against Domestic Violence)
Leigh Goodmark (Law Professor and Director, Gender Violence Clinic at the University of Maryland)
